country.name: Cook Islands
country.background: Named after Captain COOK, who sighted them in 1770, the islands became a British protectorate in 1888. By 1900, administrative control was transferred to New Zealand; in 1965, residents chose self-government in free association with New Zealand. The emigration of skilled workers to New Zealand and government deficits are continuing problems.

geo.note: the northern Cook Islands are seven low-lying, sparsely populated, coral atolls; the southern Cook Islands, where most of the population lives, consist of eight elevated, fertile, volcanic isles, including the largest, Rarotonga, at 67 sq km

location.desc: Oceania, group of islands in the South Pacific Ocean, about half way between Hawaii and New Zealand

area.comparison: 1.3 times the size of Washington, DC

maritime-claims.continental-shelf: 200 nm or to the edge of the continental margin

geo.climate: tropical oceanic; moderated by trade winds; a dry season from April to November and a more humid season from December to March
geo.terrain: low coral atolls in north; volcanic, hilly islands in south

people.ethnic-groups: Cook Island Maori (Polynesian) 87.7%, part Cook Island Maori 5.8%, other 6.5% (2001 census)
people.religions: Cook Islands Christian Church 55.9%, Roman Catholic 16.8%, Seventh-Day Adventists 7.9%, Church of Latter Day Saints 3.8%, other Protestant 5.8%, other 4.2%, unspecified 2.6%, none 3% (2001 census)

literacy.definition: age 15 and over can read and write

government.dependency: self-governing in free association with New Zealand; Cook Islands is fully responsible for internal affairs; New Zealand retains responsibility for external affairs and defense in consultation with the Cook Islands

capital.name: Avarua
capital.time-difference: UTC-10 (5 hours behind Washington, DC during Standard Time)

government.independence: none (became self-governing in free association with New Zealand on 4 August 1965 and has the right at any time to move to full independence by unilateral action)
government.national-holiday: Constitution Day, first Monday in August (1965)
government.legal-system: common law similar to New Zealand common law

executive.head-of-state: Queen ELIZABETH II (since 6 February 1952) represented by Sir Frederick GOODWIN (since 9 February 2001); New Zealand High Commissioner Linda TE PUNI (since 3 June 2010)
executive.cabinet: Cabinet chosen by the prime minister; collectively responsible to Parliament
executive.elections: the monarchy is hereditary; the UK representative appointed by the monarch; the New Zealand high commissioner appointed by the New Zealand Government; following legislative elections, the leader of the majority party or the leader of the majority coalition usually becomes prime minister

legislative.description: bicameral Parliament consists of a House of Ariki, or upper house, made up of traditional leaders and a Legislative Assembly, or lower house, (24 seats; members elected by popular vote to serve four-year terms)
legislative.elections: last held on 17 November 2010 (next to be held by 2014)
legislative.election-results: percent of vote by party - NA; seats by party - CIP 16, Demo 8

government.parties: Cook Islands Party or CIP [Henry PUNA]; Democratic Party or Demo [Dr. Terepai MAOATE]
government.membership: ACP, ADB, AOSIS, FAO, ICAO, ICRM, IFAD, IFRCS, IMO, IMSO, IOC, ITUC, OPCW, PIF, Sparteca, SPC, UNESCO, UPU, WHO, WMO
government.flag: blue, with the flag of the UK in the upper hoist-side quadrant and a large circle of 15 white five-pointed stars (one for every island) centered in the outer half of the flag

economy.overview: Like many other South Pacific island nations, the Cook Islands' economic development is hindered by the isolation of the country from foreign markets, the limited size of domestic markets, lack of natural resources, periodic devastation from natural disasters, and inadequate infrastructure. Agriculture, employing more than one-quarter of the working population, provides the economic base with major exports made up of copra and citrus fruit. Black pearls are the Cook Islands' leading export. Manufacturing activities are limited to fruit processing, clothing, and handicrafts. Trade deficits are offset by remittances from emigrants and by foreign aid overwhelmingly from New Zealand. In the 1980s and 1990s, the country lived beyond its means, maintaining a bloated public service and accumulating a large foreign debt. Subsequent reforms, including the sale of state assets, the strengthening of economic management, the encouragement of tourism, and a debt restructuring agreement, have rekindled investment and growth.
economy.agriculture-products: copra, citrus, pineapples, tomatoes, beans, pawpaws, bananas, yams, taro, coffee; pigs, poultry
economy.industries: fruit processing, tourism, fishing, clothing, handicrafts

exports.commodities: copra, papayas, fresh and canned citrus fruit, coffee; fish; pearls and pearl shells; clothing

imports.commodities: foodstuffs, textiles, fuels, timber, capital goods

telephones.assessment: Telecom Cook Islands offers international direct dialing, Internet, email, fax, and Telex
telephones.domestic: individual islands are connected by a combination of satellite earth stations, microwave systems, and VHF and HF radiotelephone; within the islands, service is provided by small exchanges connected to subscribers by open-wire, cable, and fiber-optic cable
telephones.international: country code - 682; satellite earth station - 1 Intelsat (Pacific Ocean)

communications.broadcast: 1 privately-owned TV station broadcasts from Rarotonga providing a mix of local news and overseas-sourced programs; a satellite program package is available; 6 radio stations broadcast with 1 reportedly reaching all of the islands (2009)

military.branches: no regular military forces; National Police Department (2009)

manpower.notes: defense is the responsibility of New Zealand in consultation with the Cook Islands and at its request
